newsitem.title: USA: SEC lets Fidelity give managers new stock-report.
newsitem.headline: SEC lets Fidelity give managers new stock-report.

text.p: Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund company, received approval from the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission to issue a new class of preferred stock for its senior managers, The Boston Globe reported Tuesday.

Fidelity, which has seen an exodus of its top portfolio managers over the last year, said the new stock would be used "to attract, retain, compensate and motivate" senor managers and investment people, the newspaper reported.

The new preferred stock will, which will not be transferable and will not be publicly traded, will be available to more than 500 top employees. Fidelity told the Globe that SEC approval was needed to broaden its employee stock ownership and yet remain a private company.
Since January 1995, 18 portfolio managers on the equity side alone have left the mutual fund giant, according to Alpha Equity Research Inc, a New Hampshire firm that tracks Fidelity.
Fidelity spokesmen were not available for comment.
